org.apache.juneau.rest

Class RestConfig

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.juneau.rest.RestConfig
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ServletConfig

    public class RestConfig
extends Object
implements ServletConfig
    Defines the initial configuration of a RestServlet or @RestResource annotated object.

    An extension of the ServletConfig object used during servlet initialization.

    Provides access to the following initialized resources:

    • getConfigFile() - The external configuration file for this resource.
    • getProperties() - The modifiable configuration properties for this resource.
    • getVarResolverBuilder() - The variable resolver for this resource.

    Methods are provided for overriding or augmenting the information provided by the @RestResource annotation. In general, most information provided in the @RestResource annotation can be specified programmatically through calls on this object.

    To interact with this object, simply implement the following init method in your resource class:

    public synchronized void init(RestConfig config) throws Exception { config.addPojoSwaps(CalendarSwap.RFC2822DTZ.class); config.setProperty(PARSER_debug, true); super.init(config); // Make sure this is the last line! (or just leave it out entirely) }

    Note that this method is identical to GenericServlet.init(ServletConfig) except you get access to this object instead. Also, this method can throw any exception, not just a ServletException.

    The parent init(RestServletConfig) method will construct a read-only RestContext object that contains a snapshot of these settings. If you call super.init(RestServletConfig) before you modify this config object, you won't see the changes!

    • Method Detail

      • addVars

        public RestConfig addVars(Class<?>... vars)
        Adds the specified Var classes to this config.

        These variables affect the variable resolver returned by RestRequest.getVarResolverSession() which is used to resolve string variables of the form "$X{...}".

        By default, this config includes the following variables:

        • SystemPropertiesVar
        • EnvVariablesVar
        • ConfigFileVar
        • IfVar
        • SwitchVar

        Later during the construction of RestContext, we add the following variables:

        • LocalizationVar
        • RequestVar
        • SerializedRequestAttrVar
        • ServletInitParamVar
        • UrlEncodeVar
        Parameters:
        vars - The Var classes to add to this config.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addVarContextObject

        public RestConfig addVarContextObject(String name,
                                      Object object)
        Adds a var context object to this config.

        Var context objects are read-only objects associated with the variable resolver for vars that require external information.

        For example, the ConfigFileVar needs access to this resource's ConfigFile through the ConfigFileVar.SESSION_config object that can be specified as either a session object (temporary) or context object (permanent). In this case, we call the following code to add it to the context map:

        config.addVarContextObject(SESSION_config, configFile);

        Parameters:
        name - The context object key (i.e. the name that the Var class looks for).
        object - The context object.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setConfigFile

        public RestConfig setConfigFile(ConfigFile configFile)
        Overwrites the default config file with a custom config file.

        By default, the config file is determined using the @RestResource.config() annotation. This method allows you to programmatically override it with your own custom config file.

        Parameters:
        configFile - The new config file.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

        public RestConfig setProperties(Map<String,Object> properties)

        Values in the map are added to the existing properties and are overwritten if duplicates are found.

        Parameters:

        public RestConfig addBeanFilters(Class<?>... beanFilters)
        Adds class-level bean filters to this resource.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.beanFilters() annotation.

        Values are added AFTER those found in the annotation and therefore take precedence over those defined via the annotation.

        Parameters:
        beanFilters - The bean filters to add to this config.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addSerializers

        public RestConfig addSerializers(Serializer... serializers)
        Adds class-level serializers to this resource.

        Same as addSerializers(Class...) except allows you to pass in serializer instances. The actual serializer ends up being the result of this operation using the bean filters, pojo swaps, and properties on this config:

        serializer = serializer.builder().beanFilters(beanFilters).pojoSwaps(pojoSwaps).properties(properties).build();

        Values are added AFTER those found in the annotation and therefore take precedence over those defined via the annotation.

        Parameters:
        serializers - The serializers to add to this config.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addParsers

        public RestConfig addParsers(Parser... parsers)
        Adds class-level parsers to this resource.

        Same as addParsers(Class...) except allows you to pass in parser instances. The actual parser ends up being the result of this operation using the bean filters, pojo swaps, and properties on this config:

        parser = parser.builder().beanFilters(beanFilters).pojoSwaps(pojoSwaps).properties(properties).build();

        Values are added AFTER those found in the annotation and therefore take precedence over those defined via the annotation.

        Parameters:

        public RestConfig addEncoders(Class<?>... encoders)

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.encoders() annotation.

        Values are added AFTER those found in the annotation and therefore take precedence over those defined via the annotation.

        By default, only the IdentityEncoder is included in this list.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addMimeTypes

        public RestConfig addMimeTypes(String... mimeTypes)
        Adds MIME-type definitions.

        These definitions are used in the following locations for setting the media type on responses:

        • RestRequest.getReaderResource(String)
        • Static files resolved through RestResource.staticFiles()

        Refer to MimetypesFileTypeMap.addMimeTypes(String) for an explanation of the format.

        By default, this config includes the following mime-type definitions:

        • "text/css css CSS"
        • "text/html html htm HTML"
        • "text/plain txt text TXT"
        • "application/javascript js"
        • "image/png png"
        • "image/gif gif"
        • "application/xml xml XML"
        • "application/json json JSON"
        Parameters:
        mimeTypes - The MIME-types to add to this config.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addDefaultRequestHeader

        public RestConfig addDefaultRequestHeader(String name,
                                          Object value)
        Adds class-level default HTTP request headers to this resource.

        Default request headers are default values for when HTTP requests do not specify a header value. For example, you can specify a default value for Accept if a request does not specify that header value.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.defaultRequestHeaders() annotation.

        Parameters:
        name - The HTTP header name.
        value - The HTTP header value.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addDefaultRequestHeaders

        public RestConfig addDefaultRequestHeaders(String... headers)
                                    throws RestServletException
        Adds class-level default HTTP request headers to this resource.

        Default request headers are default values for when HTTP requests do not specify a header value. For example, you can specify a default value for Accept if a request does not specify that header value.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.defaultRequestHeaders() annotation.

        Parameters:
        headers - HTTP headers of the form "Name: Value".
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).
        Throws:
        RestServletException - If header string is not correctly formatted.

      • addDefaultResponseHeader

        public RestConfig addDefaultResponseHeader(String name,
                                           Object value)
        Adds class-level default HTTP response headers to this resource.

        Default response headers are headers that will be appended to all responses if those headers have not already been set on the response object.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.defaultResponseHeaders() annotation.

        Values are added AFTER those found in the annotation and therefore take precedence over those defined via the annotation.

        Parameters:
        name - The HTTP header name.
        value - The HTTP header value.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addDefaultResponseHeaders

        public RestConfig addDefaultResponseHeaders(String... headers)
                                     throws RestServletException
        Adds class-level default HTTP response headers to this resource.

        Default response headers are headers that will be appended to all responses if those headers have not already been set on the response object.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.defaultResponseHeaders() annotation.

        Parameters:
        headers - HTTP headers of the form "Name: Value".
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).
        Throws:
        RestServletException - If header string is not correctly formatted.

      • addResponseHandlers

        public RestConfig addResponseHandlers(Class<?>... responseHandlers)
        Adds class-level response handler classes to this resource.

        Response handlers are responsible for converting various POJOs returned by REST methods into actual HTTP responses.

        By default, this config includes the following response handlers:

        • StreamableHandler
        • WritableHandler
        • ReaderHandler
        • InputStreamHandler
        • RedirectHandler
        • DefaultHandler

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.responseHandlers() annotation.

        Parameters:
        responseHandlers - The response handlers to add to this config.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addChildResource

        public RestConfig addChildResource(String path,
                                   Object child)
        Adds a child resource to this resource.

        Child resources are resources that are accessed under the path of the parent resource.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.children() annotation.

        Parameters:
        path - The child path of the resource. Must conform to RestResource.path() format.
        child - The child resource.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addChildResources

        public RestConfig addChildResources(Object... children)
        Add child resources to this resource.

        Child resources are resources that are accessed under the path of the parent resource.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.children() annotation.

        Parameters:
        children - The child resources to add to this resource. Children must be annotated with RestResource.path() to identify the child path.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

        public RestConfig setSupportedAcceptTypes(String... mediaTypes)

        There is no annotation equivalent to this method call.

        Parameters:

        This object (for method chaining).

      • setStyleSheet

        public RestConfig setStyleSheet(Object... styleSheets)
        Specifies the stylesheets that make up the contents of the page "/resource-path/styles.css".

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.stylesheet() annotation.

        The object types can be any of the following:

        • InputStream
        • Reader
        • File
        • CharSequence
        • byte[]
        The contents of all these stylesheets will be aggregated into a single page in the order they are specified in this list.
        Parameters:
        styleSheets - The new list of style sheets that make up the styles.css page.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setStyleSheet

        public RestConfig setStyleSheet(Class<?> resourceClass,
                                String resourcePath)
        Specifies the stylesheet that make up the contents of the page "/resource-path/styles.css".

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.stylesheet() annotation.

        Use this method to specify a resource located in the classpath. This call uses the Class.getResourceAsStream(String) method to retrieve the stylesheet contents.

        Parameters:
        resourceClass - The resource class used to resolve the resource stream.
        resourcePath - The path passed to the Class.getResourceAsStream(String) method. Can also be a path starting with "file://" denoting a location to pull from the file system.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addStyleSheet

        public RestConfig addStyleSheet(Object... styleSheets)
        Adds to the stylesheet that make up the contents of the page "/resource-path/styles.css".

        Same as setStyleSheet(Object...) except appends to the existing list instead of replacing.

        Parameters:
        styleSheets - The list of style sheets to add that make up the styles.css page.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addStyleSheet

        public RestConfig addStyleSheet(Class<?> resourceClass,
                                String resourcePath)
        Adds to the stylesheet that make up the contents of the page "/resource-path/styles.css".

        Same as setStyleSheet(Class,String) except appends to the existing list instead of replacing.

        Parameters:
        resourceClass - The resource class used to resolve the resource stream.
        resourcePath - The path passed to the Class.getResourceAsStream(String) method.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

        This object (for method chaining).

      • setFavIcon

        public RestConfig setFavIcon(Class<?> resourceClass,
                             String resourcePath)
        Specifies the icon contents that make up the contents of the page "/resource-path/favicon.ico".

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.favicon() annotation.

        Use this method to specify a resource located in the classpath. This call uses the Class.getResourceAsStream(String) method to retrieve the stylesheet contents.

        Parameters:
        resourceClass - The resource class used to resolve the resource stream.
        resourcePath - The path passed to the Class.getResourceAsStream(String) method. Can also be a path starting with "file://" denoting a location to pull from the file system.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • addStaticFiles

        public RestConfig addStaticFiles(Class<?> resourceClass,
                                 String staticFilesString)
        Appends to the static files resource map.

        Use this method to specify resources located in the classpath to be served up as static files.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.staticFiles() annotation.

        Parameters:
        resourceClass - The resource class used to resolve the resource streams.
        staticFilesString - A JSON string denoting a map of child URLs to classpath subdirectories. For example, if this string is "{htdocs:'docs'}" with class com.foo.MyResource, then URLs of the form "/resource-path/htdocs/..." will resolve to files located in the com.foo.docs package.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setResourceResolver

        public RestConfig setResourceResolver(Class<? extends RestResourceResolver> resourceResolver)
        Overrides the default REST resource resolver.

        The resource resolver is used to resolve instances from Class objects defined in the RestResource.children() annotation. The default value is the base class RestResourceResolver.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.resourceResolver() annotation.

        Parameters:
        resourceResolver - The new resource resolver.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setResourceResolver

        public RestConfig setResourceResolver(RestResourceResolver resourceResolver)
        Overrides the default REST resource resolver.

        Same as setResourceResolver(Class) except allows you to specify an instance instead of a class.

        Parameters:
        resourceResolver - The new resource resolver.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setPath

        public RestConfig setPath(String path)
        Sets the URL path of the resource "/foobar".

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.path() annotation.

        Parameters:
        path - The URL path of this resource.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • setCallHandler

        public RestConfig setCallHandler(Class<? extends RestCallHandler> restHandler)
        Overrides the call handler for the resource.

        The call handler is the object that handles execution of REST HTTP calls. Subclasses can be created that customize the behavior of how REST calls are handled.

        This is the programmatic equivalent to the @RestResource.callHandler() annotation.

        Parameters:
        restHandler - The new call handler for this resource.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • createPropertyStore

        protected PropertyStore createPropertyStore()
        Creates a new PropertyStore object initialized with the properties defined in this config.
        Returns:
        A new property store.

      • getConfigFile

        public ConfigFile getConfigFile()
        Returns the external configuration file for this resource.

        The configuration file location is determined via the @RestResource.config() annotation on the resource.

        The config file can be programmatically overridden by adding the following method to your resource:

        public ConfigFile createConfigFile(ServletConfig servletConfig) throws ServletException;

        If a config file is not set up, then an empty config file will be returned that is not backed by any file.

        Returns:
        The external config file for this resource. Never null.

      • getProperties

        public ObjectMap getProperties()
        Returns the configuration properties for this resource.

        The configuration properties are determined via the RestResource.properties() annotation on the resource.

        The configuration properties can be augmented programmatically by adding the following method to your resource:

        public ObjectMap createProperties(ServletConfig servletConfig) throws ServletException;

        These properties can be modified during servlet initialization. However, any modifications made after RestServlet.init(RestConfig) has been called will have no effect.

        Returns:
        The configuration properties for this resource. Never null.

      • getVarResolverBuilder

        public VarResolverBuilder getVarResolverBuilder()
        Creates the variable resolver for this resource.

        The variable resolver returned by this method can resolve the following variables:

        • SystemPropertiesVar
        • EnvVariablesVar
        • ConfigFileVar
        • IfVar
        • SwitchVar

        Note that the variables supported here are only a subset of those returned by RestRequest.getVarResolverSession().

        Returns:
        The variable resolver for this resource. Never null.
